doc.field: Drawdown in Areas with Significant Potential for Impact to Surface Waters due to Cummulative Pumping Stresses - Twin Cities Metropolitan Area, Minnesota
Drawdown in Areas with Significant Potential for Impact to Surface Waters due to Cummulative Pumping Stresses - Twin Cities Metropolitan Area, Minnesota
Metropolitan Council - Water Supply Planning Unit
Metropolitan Council - Water Supply Planning Unit

This dataset consists of aquifer drawdown projections for 2030 and 2050 in surficial aquifers where withdrawals from a major aquifer may directly impact surface water features within the Twin Cities metropolitan area. Where aquifer drawdown is predicted to be greater than 3 feet (0.9144 meters), the likelihood of impacts on surface water features is assumed to increase. Aquifer drawdown was predicted using a regional groundwater flow model of the Twin Cities metropolitan area (Metro Model 2) and Metropolitan Council water demand projections.
More information about this process is provided in the 2009 Metropolitan Council report 'Twin Cities Metropolitan Area Regional Groundwater Flow Model Version 2.00 - Technical Report in Support of the Metropolitan Area Master Water Supply Plan', which is available online at www.metrocouncil.org/environment/WaterSupply/metrogroundwatermodeldatasets.htm.

<?xml version="1.0"?><metadata><idinfo><citation><citeinfo><title>Drawdown in Areas with Significant Potential for Impact to Surface Waters due to Cummulative Pumping Stresses - Twin Cities Metropolitan Area, Minnesota</title><origin>Metropolitan Council - Water Supply Planning Unit</origin><pubinfo><publish>Metropolitan Council</publish></pubinfo><pubdate>Unpublished material</pubdate><onlink>ftp://gisftp.metc.state.mn.us/GroundwaterModelResults.zip</onlink></citeinfo></citation><descript><abstract>This dataset consists of aquifer drawdown projections for 2030 and 2050 in surficial aquifers where withdrawals from a major aquifer may directly impact surface water features within the Twin Cities metropolitan area. Where aquifer drawdown is predicted to be greater than 3 feet (0.9144 meters), the likelihood of impacts on surface water features is assumed to increase. Aquifer drawdown was predicted using a regional groundwater flow model of the Twin Cities metropolitan area (Metro Model 2) and Metropolitan Council water demand projections.

More information about this process is provided in the 2009 Metropolitan Council report 'Twin Cities Metropolitan Area Regional Groundwater Flow Model Version 2.00 - Technical Report in Support of the Metropolitan Area Master Water Supply Plan', which is available online at www.metrocouncil.org/environment/WaterSupply/metrogroundwatermodeldatasets.htm.</abstract><purpose>The 2005 Minnesota Legislature directed the metropolitan Council to "carry out planning activities addressing the water supply needs of the metropolitan area" (Minnesota Statutes, Section 473.1565). Specifically the Council is charged with developing a base of technical information for water supply planning decisions and to prepare a metropolitan area master water supply plan. This dataset supports this charge.</purpose><supplinf>Twin Cities Seven County Metropolitan Area. This includes the counties of Anoka, Carver, Dakota, Hennepin, Ramsey, Scott and Washington in Minnesota.</supplinf></descript><timeperd><timeinfo><sngdate><caldate>20091201</caldate></sngdate></timeinfo><current>Data is based upon 2008 community water supply plan water demand projections and a regional groundwater flow model calibration completed in Spring 2009.</current></timeperd><status><progress>Complete</progress><update>As Needed</update></status><spdom><bounding><westbc>-405446.481828</westbc><eastbc>-537860.309332</eastbc><northbc>5049392.491804</northbc><southbc>4910507.311828</southbc></bounding></spdom><keywords><place><placekey>Twin Cities, Anoka County, Carver County, Dakota County, Hennepin County, Ramsey County, Scott County, Washington County</placekey></place><theme><themekey>water supply planning, aquifer drawdown, surface water, interaction, Metro Model 2</themekey></theme></keywords><accconst>None</accconst><useconst>By acceptance of this data, the user agrees to include a copy of the metadata record, including the liability disclaimer, whenever the user transmits or provides the GIS data (or any portion of it) to another user.</useconst><browse><browsen>None available</browsen><browsed /></browse><crossref><citeinfo><title>wattbldcl2030
wattbldcl2050</title></citeinfo></crossref><native>Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 2; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.2.1.1332</native><ptcontac><cntinfo><cntperp><cntorg>Metropolitan Council</cntorg><cntper>Lanya Ross</cntper></cntperp><cntpos>Sr. Environmental Scientist, Water Supply Planning</cntpos><cntaddr><address>390 Robert St. North</address><city>St Paul</city><state>MN</state><postal>55101-1805</postal></cntaddr><cntvoice>651-602-1066</cntvoice><cntfax>651-602-1130</cntfax><cntemail>lanya.ross@metc.state.mn.us</cntemail></cntinfo></ptcontac></idinfo><dataqual><attracc><attraccr>The absolute residual mean (mean error) of the regional groundwater flow model is 5.03 meters (16.50 feet). Models are abstract approximations of reality; therefore, all models have inherent uncertainty imbedded within them. This uncertainty within the model will always lead to some uncertainty in any predictions made by the model. Sources of uncertainty in the Metro Model 2 stem from:

- An incomplete understanding of the geologic conditions in the Twin Cities area, including the presence of undetected features (e.g., faults, changes in glacial deposits);	

- An incomplete understanding of groundwater flow conditions in the Twin Cities;

- Data gaps in groundwater levels (particularly for deeper aquifers);

- Data gaps on the hydraulic conductivity of the aquifers and aquitard due to a small set of existing pumping tests;

- Undocumented or unreported groundwater withdrawals;

- Limited base-flow data for streams (particularly for the Mississippi River through Minneapolis and St. Paul);

- Limited or non-existent information on the permeability of lake bottoms;

- The necessary simplifications, lumping of conditions, and time-averaging of observations that is needed in order to build and calibrate a groundwater flow model;

- Incomplete and evolving understanding of how and where recharge through infiltration takes place;

- The need to exclude very detailed, site-specific hydrogeologic data in a regional model; and

- The conceptualization of groundwater flow on a regional basis for the purpose of this model (the evaluation of groundwater supply).

Continuing efforts must be made to reduce model uncertainty and increase model uniqueness. As new data are obtained and new understandings of regional hydrogeology evolve, the model will be re-optimized. In particularly, the following types of information will likely have an impact on reducing model uncertainty:

- New estimates of hydraulic conductivity from new pumping tests (expressed as prior knowledge in the model)
- Additional calibration data, such as synoptic water levels and baseflow data
- Better understanding of the water-transmitting characteristics of the glacial drift deposits
- Refined estimates of recharge, particularly leakage from lakes</attraccr></attracc><complete>The entire seven county geographic area is covered</complete><lineage><procstep><procdesc>2030 and 2050 water demand was projected for each municipality or municipal water supply system in the Twin Cities metropolitan area and applied to the regional groundwater flow modle using the method described in Appendix E of the 2009 Metropolitan Council report: Twin Cities Metropolitan Area Regional Groundwater Flow Model Version 2.00 - Technical Report in Support of the Metropolitan Area Master Water Supply Plan.  A groundwater flow model scenario was run for each of the demand projection years and model-predicted aquifer drawdown (compared to average 1995-2005 conditions) was recorded.

Model results were exported as ESRI Spatial Analyst raster files and clipped to the extent of the shapefile:GwSwInteract.shp.</procdesc></procstep><srcinfo><srcscale /></srcinfo><procstep><procdesc Sync="TRUE">Dataset copied.</procdesc><srcused Sync="TRUE">N:\EQA\WaterSupply\MAPS_Make_A_Map\MAM_WaterSupply_2Mar09\MAM_WatSUp_Metadata_23Apr09\SWGWdrawdown</srcused><procdate Sync="TRUE">20091208</procdate><proctime Sync="TRUE">10043000</proctime></procstep></lineage></dataqual><spdoinfo><indspref /><direct>Raster</direct><mgmg3obj /><mgmg3til /></spdoinfo><spref><vertdef><altsys><altunits>Meters</altunits></altsys><depthsys><depthdn>Mean sea level</depthdn><depthdu>Meters</depthdu></depthsys></vertdef><horizsys><planar><gridsys><gridsysn>Universal Transverse Mercator</gridsysn><utm><utmzone>15</utmzone></utm></gridsys><planci><plandu>meters</plandu><coordrep><absres>497.796344</absres><ordres>497.796344</ordres></coordrep></planci></planar><geodetic><horizdn>NAD83</horizdn><ellips>GRS80</ellips></geodetic></horizsys></spref><distinfo><distliab>NOTICE: The Geographic Information System (GIS) Data to which this notice is attached are made available pursuant to the Minnesota Government Data Practices Act (Minnesota Statutes Chapter 13). - NOTICE.RTF, an important notice about this dataset that can be read by any word processing software.
